title: How many total Fast Charge (>22kW) public charging points for electric vehicles will be installed in the European Union in 2020?
preds:
Didnt keep track well enough 
Whats the update frequency?
Previous forecast was 26000+ from ytd august extrapollation.
Currently 21000+ from presumably at least 9 months.
Cointoss for me’

If you read the link above which  I also added herr
"European Alternative Fuels Observatory"
The chart in the article shows #s

As a warning to those answering this question please look at this reference which shows when the data was last updated. For this question and many others the last data update was Sept 2020. Assume it will be updated in January using Dec 2020 data. This data is NOT timely.
https://www.eafo.eu/knowledge-center/data-updated

Maybe my probabilities of >26k was a tad bit optimistic. It might be that COVID has slowed down deployment. This is anecdotal but points towards the current situation being more difficult to deploy in than other years. I also believe car sales are down which might have a slowing effect on deployment on EC chargers. https://insideevs.com/news/454268/ionity-300-fast-charging-stations-europe/

YoY Delta
'17: 27% 
'18: 35% 
'19: 41% Current delta: 41% (upper limit being 57% or 23,824) I should've done this math a long time ago.

hedging down from 100 a little for the lower bucket. @dglid  how's your model holding?
cheers
Not informed very much, heavily influenced by crowd forecast. Will update in a week with more info
Now there are already 21,000. Because of covid i don't expect that much more growth

Scrap that, my last calcs were wrong. Linear extrapolation gives 23975. But with most trends hinting towards faster growth towards the end of the year I think there is a fair chance we might exceed 26k and some small chance we will get past 30k. >30k is certainly not smaller than 0.5% chance as many others believe.

it is currently at 21384 with data update in sep. That means just linear extrapolation with data update assumed 15 sep brings us to 30253 by EoY. Factors that might influence this extrapolation are: Green stimulus (accelerating), less holidays than the slow summer (accelerating), second wave covid (decelerating), economy and EV adoption growing (accelerating) so on net I think it is more likely we will exceed 30k than fall short of it.

Stats updated [1] as of Oct 1st [2]. 21,384 through that period. Updating model [3] accordingly. See bottom-right-most graph on sheet. [1] https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats
[2] https://www.eafo.eu/knowledge-center/data-updated
[3] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1156249529

10/11 - data suddenly at 21,384 Fast charging points in the EU without a date its impossible to know when/how to gauge the data. Suddenly they found an extra two thousand charging stations in the last week. GAME OVER.

The EAFO update shows that the numbers of charging points stands at 21384. That's only 600 off the 22k-26k bin. Considering that, on average, 700 chargers have been installed each month it seems likely that at least 600 will be installed in the final three months of 2020. I think worsening weather and Christmas may slow the rate of installations but not by much. I doubt Covid restrictions will have much of an impact as they didn't during the first wave.  For this prediction, I have just used the average rate of installations for 2020. This was 698 per month and based on that my forecast is 23234 new chargers by the end of 2020. This figure is a slightly less than my base-rate as I feel opportunities to install new chargers will be effected by factors mentioned in the first paragraph.
10/2 - data still the same at 19,543 Fast charging points in the EU same as it was 2 weeks ago. When you have no data, you sit on the fence.

Hat-tip @Tim-S for pointing out to me that my finely crafted linear extrapolation was based on the incorrect assumption that the data was timely and current. The data base has no time stamp, and when you download the data instead of the daily data, all you get is the same chart and chart points. Again, anything but timely. So unless there is another source, one is left to do a total swag based on wind direction and level of alcohol in your blood.

9/23 there are 19,543 Fast charging points in the EU with 3 months left to install more. Growth in the first 9 months was 4407 points. Simple linear extrapolation (which is all I know) yields about another 1469 fast charging points installed by year end for a total of 21,012 fast charging points. Detune for lack of budget and Covid. Increase for the EU's desire to go more electric and green - assume a wash.

already 19543
if next months just as strong-> x1.5
downside risk given covid?
As of today 19543 stations set up.

I now think more than 22,000 rather than marginally less, based on Europe's continuing investment towards towards faster-charging and e-vehicle development. 
Sales in e-vehicles also seems to be holding more steady than fossil fuel which would tie-in with overall strategy: 
https://www.edie.net/news/8/IEA--Electric-vehicle-sales-will-continue-to-rise-despite-Covid-19-crisis/

It gets more and more likely we'll see more than 22,000 stations up and running by the end of the year. I don't have an overview on the time period in which the bulk of the stations have been installed in the last years. Maybe the growth period is already over and there won't be many additions in the coming months? Or do we have constant installments over the whole year? We'll see the growth patterns in the coming months I guess ...

Currently at 19543 [1], which is about 4k since the beginning of the year. Adding another 4k puts it at 23k.  I am going to bump more to the 22k bucket. Will keep an eye on the next month's results. [1] https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats
Current count 19,543 due to source from question
Adjusted last bracket down a bit more, after looking at other's rationales.

Data was updated to 19543 at some point after my last forecast. This leaves us with a 30% increase within around half a year.  This way the bracket boundaries in percent growth for the next half year are -8%|12.5%|33%|53%. The last bracket is too high, as 1.53^2>2.3 such that this would imply a higher growth rate than in 2015. First bracket gets 0% as well, as I cannot think of any reason for a decline in charging stations.  Forecast without looking at crowd: 0|20|50|30|0 crowd: 0|50|49|1|0
Adjuster forecast: 0|23|50|27|0
They updated the data, and about 4,000 were produced in the first two quarters of 2020. If it follows that rate we should reach the 22,000 - 26,000 bucket.

The EAFO data has been updated and shows 1686 chargers have been installed during April, May, and June. Considering much of the EU was under lockdown I am once again surprised at how many chargers have been installed. I seem to under-estimate the number of installs at each update so I've upped the 22K-26K bin by a few points to account for this.

Stats updated as of July 1st [1]. 19,543 through that period. Updating model [2] accordingly.  I'm a bit more bullish on bin 3 due to the fact that I'm assuming an average with an exponential growth trajectory, which seems to continue to follow higher-than-linear growth. In 2019, growth grew by 4,000. In 2020, we've already surpassed 4,000 in the first two quarters, so there's a good reason we'll have at least another 4,000 this year, putting us at 23,543 at end of year. [1] https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats
[2] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1156249529
New stimulus will not be that fast I think

I've continued to use the linear regression model (adjusted for Covid) I used in my previous forecast. However, I have now updated the model to include the EAFO data published for Jan, Feb, and March. Based on previous years growth I didn't expect so many chargers to be installed in the first three months of the year. This may be a sign of things to come so it seems reasonable to include it in my forecast. I've basically just divided the YTD installations by three to get a monthly average of 907 and weighted this against my overall forecast. Again, the monthly averages are adjusted for periods which may be effected by lockdown.

Big Reversal. I'm afraid of the 2019 numbers having been mis-stated on the written backgrounder to the question. 
Those GJP Bosses are sly!...   :-) Checking the graphs today, I learned 2019 total graphs at 15,136 compared to the posted "fact" of 17,056. No small difference.  2020 YTD on the chart shows 17,857, so bucket 1 is safely "toast" but bucket 2's limit is still a long 4150 with 7/12's of the year left with 2721 in the first 5/12's... it'll take over 6870 total this year to break bucket 2. So I have to now heavily loaded back for bucket 2 and backed out of 3 where I'd felt we'd reach from the inaccurate "start base" I planted in my head.  Even if it was an innocent mistake, I've learned to "question" better than ever doing this derby, so GJP has already earned my permanent gratitude.
Adjusting pending some clarification. I am doubting the dataset we've been provided and have sent in a clarification question. standby.
The average is a little more than 2000 per year since 2011. They should easily exceed 18k, but not 22k.
Based on current YTD and past two year growth cycles.

YoY Increase 2012-19 averaged 185.71% versus a 2017-2019 average of 143.88%. Based on last year's figure of 15,136 that yields a range of 21,778 to 28,109 with 17,857 already installed.[1] The total range is 6,331 4% of the range is below 22,000
66% between 22,000 and 26,000
33% between 26,000 and 30,000 Comments welcome as always. This is a pretty crude initial forecast. [1]https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats

Current total from March (HT @dglid) is 17,857 [1], meaning that less than 18k is most likely out. A second degree projection from previous years' data puts the end-of-the-year value at 19.5k, which should sit at the floor [2]. I have an upper bound of 24.5k in the same sheet based on the projection of the total number of stations with the %age of fast-chart stations of the total (9.23%; scenario B) being equal to that from last year. [1] https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats
[2] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1z2xptBX8-R0QDkJ9w2i6v4JBUY92RITsINrMwL7nUJE/edit#gid=0
Germany doubles electric car rebates this morning. https://www.autonews.com/sales/germany-doubles-ev-incentives-excludes-internal-combustion-cars-stimulus-program

Weighing down my second outside view to 1/3 due to lack of updated data => 1|41|33|23|2
Slight downward adjustment for corona: 2|45|33|19|1
Adjustment for current crowd (7|56|26|6|5): 3|50|33|13|1
Quadratic regression gives us around 20,600. Exponential regression gives us higher, but I'm not sure it's as appropriate to use here.

Refining my 1st forecast. [1]  A 2nd degree polynomial growth would be 20,141. Exponential growth would be 26,180. I'll use the average (23,161) as my median and adjust confidence to time until forecast close. [2] [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1035850
[2] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1156249529

2,721 net additional charging points in 2020 already, bringing total to 17,857 [1]. Data last updated in March, I'm assuming represents by end of March [2]. So, 2,721 growth in Q1 2020.  Assuming quarterly growth continued at that rate, we'd arrive at 28,741 by end of year. Covid likely dampens those numbers a bit, let's assume roughly that a full quarter's growth is lost, putting us at 26,020 by end of 2020.  I'll use 26,020 as my mean. I'd like to cheat upward a bit because I assume that installations continue increasing just like they have YoY, meaning that Q2-Q4 each would have produced more than Q1 under normal circumstances due to upward growth slope. However, given where the crowd is at, I can hedge and re-evaluate as data is updated throughout the year while still being ahead of the crowd in the upper bins. Pre-mortem if lower:
* Covid slows down installs even after countries reopen (contrary to my assumption that these types of infrastructure services are likely considered essential services that could either continue working in some capacity during shutdown or start back up early)
* Covid compresses budgets and projects are cancelled (like this one [3] announced in May where they are planning to complete ~30 installs for Europe's largest electric car charging park by August)
* Bad assumption that growth in later quarters would have been significantly larger than Q1 growth under normal circumstances. Pre-mortem for higher:
* Crews are able to "catch up" and complete installations that they were unable to get to during shutdown in addition to planned installations later in year
* Growth truly does have an upward slope, meaning Q1 isn't representative of later quarters (assuming quasi-normal situations) [1] https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats (change date filter in top right to "Date" or "2020 YTD")
[2] https://www.eafo.eu/knowledge-center/data-updated (see bottom left "Infrastructure" chart, "Electricity", column; note top of page where it says last overall update was May 1st, so assuming that March numbers include all of March.)
[3] https://www.tesvolt.com/en/presse/tesvolt-supplies-storage-systems-for-europe%E2%80%99s-largest-electric-car-charging-park__prr40.html

Sure, why not..? When you build something new, it is challenging. Once it becomes systematic, it is hard to louse that up... despite C19, consider that labor and real estate are simultaneously strained yet discounted. Here is an interesting read: https://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/uk/Documents/energy-resources/deloitte-uk-electric-vechicles-WEB.pdf
I'll temper my enthusiasm for charging stations a bit.

After reading a few comments below, found another angle of analysis:  the actual total increase in charging stations, by year, and so I added three more estimates, for a total of 11 now.  This is the new distribution, plus adjusted per my last comment, because I don't believe the higher end, and thus shifted down to lower.

Taking the data available on the EAFO, I tried a number of different methods for estimating the growth for 2020:  using 2018 GR; using 2017 GR; averaging for prior 4 years, 2016-19; basing growth in 2020 using GR change between 2019 and 2018; using pattern (2019 is about half of 2017 GR; 2018 is about half of 2016 GR; so 2020 is half of 2018 GR).  I consider each to be a data point, as a distribution of estimates, and proportioned each to 100%.  Lastly, I shifted some from top range, because I don't believe that's happening, given that a huge recession is going on, and put it into lowest bucket, which seems like it should be higher, plus, while two were in the 22-26K bucket, both were barely, in the low 22K, so I moved half of that into next lower bucket. Then I rounded to closest multiple of 5 that makes sense.

Last year...a full year not disrupted by covid...saw just under 5,000 charges installed of roughly 400 a month. The impact of covid is probably 3-4 months of installs so 1200 to 1600 installs (assuming similar rate of monthly installation). So installation capacity in 2020 likely less than 5000 even assuming that more were planned and the process has become leaner/faster. Top end under that logic is around the 22,000 installed chargers. But what about demand? Pressure on capital projects? I'd say that 22k is the likely top end of realistic installations but there is a chance this could go higher. 26k installs amd above is a pipe dream as is near-zero installed chargers

There will have to be more than 30,000 per year to achieve the goals outlined on page 25 of https://www.transportenvironment.org/sites/te/files/publications/01%202020%20Draft%20TE%20Infrastructure%20Report%20Final.pdf.  Despite COVID-19, I feel they will trend towards these goals (appearing to be just under 100k/year). Per page 15 of the report, fast and ultra-fast chargers account for about 5% of public chargers (approximately 5K).  Therefore, and to @Kai-Gondlach's point earlier, its hard to see too much of an increase from the previous year.

Current numbers (15,136 in 2019) and increase of the last years indicates annual growth of roughly 3,000 charging points each year; unlikely to increase substantially in one year, especially given the COVID19-outbreak.
https://www.eafo.eu/electric-vehicle-charging-infrastructure
See https://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/STUD/2018/617470/IPOL_STU(2018)617470_EN.pdf for more information

Misread numbers. Last year close to 4,000 installed. If similar number this year then would leave more than 18,000. Would have to see 25% fewer installed this year to still see fewer than 18,000 and that feels like a siginificant drop. Hasn't been that much of a slowdown in installation in any other year. But it feels similarly probably it could be below or just over 18,000 with the balance tipping to just over.

In the last 5 years the highest year on year increase was 3,533. This would still leave the number below 18,000. There is no evidence of any deals or push by the EU or member states to install more and COVID will have an inevitable impact on installation rates.

Environmental concerns are going to get more pronounced over time, so the desirability to switch and increase investment in battery tech and charging points will remain for some time. Battery capacity is improving and cost reducing over the years, and increasing fast charging points would help encourage sales/leasing of cars. Coronavirus will likely hamper an increase for the first half of the year, but overall I think the investment will I still go ahead to a similar extent. 22K would look on trend with the last few years, and I think within 10% of this is very likely.

Following the trend on the data site provided, somewhere in the range of 20k looks about right. The infrastructure impacts of the corona virus are yet to be determined, but will probably tend to interrupt projects, bringing this average down.
News reporting that a further 68 are now ready and in use.
I am interested in the transition of the car industry to co2 free or neutral emissions.

*around 9,000 CCS fast charge points and 640 ultra-fast chargers across
Europe. there will be about 200,000 public charge points in the EU while at least 2,1 million EVs are expected on the road in the EU by 2020
https://www.transportenvironment.org/sites/te/files/publications/01%202020%20Draft%20TE%20Infrastructure%20Report%20Final.pdf *Currently, there are different ways to count the number of public charge points and there is no harmonized methodology at EU level. Member States report the number of public charge points they count to EAFO but do not always provide details on their methodology EAFO has recently agreed with the European Commission to harmonise the method to report the number of fast chargers per country and avoid double-counting of CCS and CHAdeMO plugs typically offered on the same charging points but which can not be used at the same time As of the end of 2019, there will be around 185,000 public charge points in the EU, or 7 cars for each
point, which is enough for the current market. There is a clear preference for slow (AC) public
charge points (61% public chargers) but the network of fast and ultra-fast charge points is
progressing well with around 9,000 CCS fast charge points and 640 ultra-fast chargers across
Europe. Fast chargers are mostly located in the urban corridor stretching from the southern UK to
the Netherlands, through German Rhineland, Southern Germany and Switzerland.1
Perhaps some work will get done after all.

Yearly growth rates according to https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats:
2014 96% 2015 130% 2016 53% 2017 68% 2018 27% 2019 35%. Geometric mean is 53% for the last 7 years, 42% for the last three and 31 for the last two years. Extrapolating the 17857 stations in 2020 to date (accessed at 12.04, unsure about how recent the data is) gives an estimated growth of 78%. Bracket boundaries: 19%, 45%, 71%, 98% Outside view 1 last years: 1|60|32|6|3 
Outside view 2 growth this year: 0|3|35|60|2
Combined outside view: 0|22|34|42|2 (weighing the second one as around 2/3 as it seems more relevant)
Adjustment for Corona (not too large, since there has been significant growth this year despite lockdown measures) 0|26|35|42|1
Adjustment for crowd forecast (6|66|20|4|4): 0|35|37|27|1

At the end of 2019 there were 15,136 Fast Charging stations. 4K units were installed in 2019, 2.5K were installed in 2018. So far in 2020 there are 17,857 units installed Total. My previous estimate was done after too many wine glasses at dinner, sorry to have mislead you. If the EU countries can install 4K units in this environment fantastic.
I'm with Bob, @bobrown except the "brakes" were put on AFTER nearly a quarter had passed, so I'm heavy on the 18-22 bucket and none on the lowest one.

Given the covid-19 impact across most of the EU, I am dumbing down my EV charger number. Money has to come from somewhere for social support programs. Reducing the number of EV chargers is a victimless repurposing of funds.

Using linear regression to analyse the last eight years of fast charger growth suggests there would be around 5000 (5211) new chargers installed in the EU during 2020. There seems to be a lot of variance from year to year with only 2418 chargers installed in 2018 compared with 5901 in 2019. So if this year was a 'normal' year the number installed could rise or fall significantly from the 2019 figure. Since the number installed last year was unusually high I think 5211 would be a fair non-Covid estimate. But this year is not a normal year and is very much effected by Covid-19. Considering most EU countries are on lockdown and installing chargers is not essential I cannot see many chargers being installed in April or May. March will have been effected too although installations should have been carried out as normal in January and February (though I'm not sure how many chargers would usually be installed in the middle of winter). As for the rest of the year, that remains to be seen. I suspect things will pick up but we cannot rule out the possibility of a second wave of the virus or economic issues effecting EU countries ability to install chargers. With the above in mind I am going to say around 20000 chargers will be installed in the EU by the end of 2020. This is a rise of 3000 but will depend on how Covid-19 is handled and how EU countries recover from the inevitable economic repercussions.
Production rate is increasing steadily but not ready for a high takeoff just yet. Economic slowdown due to COVID-19 may also play a role.

Hattip to @Ewell_Gregoor for references and detailed analysis. Gretta needs more charging stations - that we agree. How many will be realized is the question. There will be lots of money thrown around on the continent this year, but will it end up in charging station installations? Will people be put back to work installing, will planning and approvals get done with people working from home?

Once again, one wishes that the writers of these Qs would pay more attention to language.  Does "will be installed...in 2020" mean "will have been installed by the end of 2020" (including prior-year installations), or "will be installed during 2020" (meaning only new installations)?  This is a nontrivial difference, unlike my usual nitpicking.  I am guessing it means the former, but am probably wrong.

So let's set a baseline on this one:
Currently there are 17k chargers and following the historic trend this would range between 18k to 40k based purely on the stats. which doesn't help tremendously with the question
There are a number of orders placed for kit e.g. [1]
The issue for this year is how much of the expansion will or even can continue with the concequences of Covid-19.  Dropping Oil price seriously hamper the demand forelectric cars and the lack of the ability of installers to actually get out and work for 3-6months this year will hinder deployment
[1] https://insideevs.com/news/392051/ionity-ordered-customized-chargers-abb/
Note to self to follow ABB's investor page for info on further orders.

Found this recent article, Tesla have superchargers on the boat as we speak. Musk has a good track record at following through with his promises. https://thedriven.io/2020/04/01/tesla-ramps-up-first-v3-supercharger-installations-for-europe/

Outside View:  To gain the outside perspective i have looked at the increments over the last 4 years. 
2016 - 1794
2017 - 3548
2018 - 2418
2019 - 5901 I will remove the 2016 data as electric cars have increases and thus that data set is has lost significance.  The average created over the past 3 years = 3995 + 2019 data (5901)/2 = Regression to the mean = 4948.  From a purely outside perspective, 4948 + 17056 = 22,004.  at a pure outside perspective i would go 50/50 between 18-22 and 26-30 Factors to consider 
Negative
- Covid, less work output 
- Less demand to buy cars 
- Recession, drop in GDP, 
-  less of a priority  Positive 
- EU TE infrastructure a high priority as part of the green commitment and the report is ambitious. According to the report cited below, remembering this was pre covid, says fast charging is likely to surge and the aims are 50kw+ chargers to increase to 8,000 over the next 2 years. This leaves room for 22-50kw.  It is likely in the first two months to the covid lockdown more were made as to created 8,000 over 24 month (8000/24) 333. 333 x 2.5 months to productivity drop =832.  Factoring outside and inside, I think we can expect around 20,000 by the end of the year.  Things to keep an eye on,
- any news relating directly to the question
- lockdown ends
- Changes to EU commitments
- Budget Re-allocations https://www.transportenvironment.org/sites/te/files/publications/01%202020%20Draft%20TE%20Infrastructure%20Report%20Final.pdf
https://www.eafo.eu/alternative-fuels/electricity/charging-infra-stats Thoughts?

The shut ups of industries is going to happen by U-curve and not by V-curve after shutdowns due to Covid-19 impact of EU-member. Any demand by EU citizens is going to recover by an S-curve over 12 till 18 months. The people will behave strong risk averse and will delay nearly all high cost demands, example is the recovery of demand after shutdown of Wuhan in April 2020. Shops are open, a few people looking, but nearly nobody demand others like food. The demand curve slope will remain low over a period of 9 months until a vaccine against SARS-Cov-19 is available. Even several hundreds billions will be offered for support of economical recovery of EU member states and industries. The top priority is push of recovery of any economical activity instead of push of specific expensive infrastructure parts. 5G infrastructure support will be seen more important than electrical vehicles infrastructure support.
